title: Chris Silverwood says England will go back to basics in bid to regain Ashes
text:

England will go back to basics in their bid to become the 'most respected' team in the world and regain the Ashes Down Under.

That is the vision of new head coach Chris Silverwood who is out to help skipper Joe Root find consistent success in a Test team that has veered wildly under the departed Trevor Bayliss.

The World Cup winning success of the white ball team came at the price of a Test team who were always in danger of being bundled out for under a hundred at the altar of 'positive cricket'.

But with managing director Ashley Giles making it clear that the balance now needs to swing back towards a stronger and more competitive Test side, Silverwood delivered his plan at Lord's ahead of his first assignment to New Zealand this month.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

“My first job is helping Joe, supporting him, making sure the Test team starts moving forward so when we go to Australia in two years time we can make a real impact out there,” said Silverwood who has been promoted from bowling coach.

“It needs work. One thing we’ll look at is building a batting group that can bat long periods of time. Stack runs up and put pressure on.

“It sounds old fashioned but we’ve got to recognise that we need to look at that. We need the right people in the right places.

“We want to bat long periods of time and then we want to create a bowling attack that is absolutely relentless and we saw some examples of that this summer. The Aussies made our lives really difficult.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Joe and I had a good long conversation yesterday. I want to make sure that from the get go, Joe and I are aligned with how we're going to go about taking the Test team forward and these are his thoughts as well.”

Silverwood will have Graham Thorpe and Paul Collingwood as two of his three assistants with a bowling coach yet to be appointed, possibly former England bowler Jon Lewis who has been working with the young Lions.

And in a week where players have been in the spotlight once more off the field, Silverwood confirmed that the midnight curfew will remain in place for all players and staff on duty with respect remaining the key word.

“You want to be successful, but it's how you are successful as well,” he added. “It's winning in the right spirit of the game. Winning with a little bit of class, and respecting your opposition as well.

“It’s the way you win that helps you become the most respected, keep driving the culture and when we are on the field, we’re role models.”
description: England's new coach has been outlining his blueprint to return England to the world's 'most respected' team
